content.text: The contrapositive of A => B is the statement ~B => ~A.
content.example: For example, the contrapositive of 'if x is rational then x^2 + 9 > 3' then x is not rational.

content.text: The implication A => B and its contrapositive ~B => ~A are said to be logically equivalent because they tell us exactly the same information.

content.description: We can explain this using a truth table which considers every possibility for whether A and B are true.

cases.implication_analysis: Sam is in the library and he is reading. This is consistent with A => B.
Sam is in the library but he is not reading. This is inconsistent with A => B.
Sam is not in the library. The hypothesis is false, so the implication cannot be tested.
Sam is not reading and he is in the library. This is consistent with ~B => ~A.

content.note: An implication only tells us something if the hypothesis is true. If the hypothesis is false, then ~B => ~A cannot be tested.

content.text: The implication A => B and its contrapositive ~B => ~A are logically equivalent because they always have the same truth value.
If the implication A => B is proven by proving its contrapositive ~B => ~A, we call this a proof by contrapositive.

content.problem: Let n be an integer. Prove that if n^2 - 4n + 5 is even, then n is odd.

steps: The contrapositive is: If n is even then n^2 - 4n + 5 is odd.
If n is even then there exists an integer k for which n = 2k.
= 2(2k^2 - 4k + 2) + 1 which is odd.
This proves the contrapositive and hence the original statement.

content.problem: Let n be a positive integer. Prove that if n = 2 mod 3 then n is not a perfect square.
content.note: n = 2 mod 3 means that n has remainder 2 when divided by 3.

steps: The contrapositive is: If n is a perfect square then n = 0 or 1 mod 3.
{if the remainder when divided by 3 is not 2, then it must be 0 or 1}
Suppose n is a perfect square, so n = k^2 for some integer k.
There are three cases to consider:
Case 1: If k = 0 mod 3 then k = 3q for some integer q.
Therefore n = k^2 = (3q)^2 = 9q^2 = 3(3q^2), so n = 0 mod 3.
Case 2: If k = 1 mod 3 then k = 3q + 1 for some integer q.
Case 3: If k = 2 mod 3 then k = 3q + 2 for some integer q.
Therefore if n is a perfect square then n = 0 or 1 mod 3.
This proves the original statement: If n = 2 mod 3 then n is not a perfect square.

subsections.title: H - Proof by Contradiction: Reductio ad Absurdum

content.text: When people talk about proof by contradiction, they are normally referring to reductio ad absurdum which is Latin for 'reduction to absurdity'. In this form of argument we show that attempting to disprove a statement inevitably leads to a ridiculous, absurd, or impractical conclusion. For example, if we end up with 1 = 0, or that an odd number is also an even number, we regard this as absurd. If the result is absurd or impossible, and all the reasoning is correct, then the only conclusion is that the hypothesis is false.

To use reductio ad absurdum, we start with the negation (opposite) of the conclusion, and correctly prove that this leads to a contradiction with the hypothesis. We hence deduce that the assumption was false, so the conclusion must be true.
content.formal_description: For a hypothesis A and conclusion B, we show that (A AND ~B) => (C AND ~C) where C is some statement which is contradicted by ~C. Since C AND ~C is always false, A AND ~B is false. So, if A is true, then B must also be true. This is the implication A => B.
content.note: Reductio ad absurdum is only valid if correct reasoning leads to a contradiction!

content.text: Proof by contradiction is an indirect proof because we do not start with the hypothesis, but rather the opposite of the conclusion.

steps: Suppose log_2(3) is rational
Therefore log_2(3) = p/q where p, q in Z, q != 0
Therefore 3 = 2^(p/q)
Therefore 3^q = 2^p
The left hand side is always odd and the right hand side is always even. This is a contradiction.
Therefore our original supposition is false, and log_2(3) is irrational.

content.problem: The number sqrt(2) is the length of a diagonal of a square with side length 1. Prove that sqrt(2) is irrational.

steps: Suppose sqrt(2) is rational, so sqrt(2) = p/q for some (positive) integers p and q, q != 0.
We assume this fraction has been written in lowest terms, so p and q have no common factors.
Squaring both sides, 2 = p^2/q^2
Therefore p^2 = 2q^2 .... (1)
Therefore p^2 is even, and so p must be even.
Thus p = 2k for some k in Z^+.
Substituting into (1), 4k^2 = 2q^2
Therefore q^2 = 2k^2
Therefore q^2 is even, and so q must be even.
This is a contradiction, as p and q have no common factors.
Thus our original supposition is false, and sqrt(2) is irrational.

content.problem: Prove that there are infinitely many prime numbers.

steps: Suppose there are only a finite number n of prime numbers, which we label p_1, p_2, ...., p_n.
Every positive integer greater than 1 is either a member of this list, or is divisible by a member of this list.
Notice that:
- N > p_k for all k = 1, ...., n, therefore N is not a member of the list.
- If we divide N by any p_k, k = 1, ...., n, then the remainder is 1.
Therefore N is not divisible by any p_k.
This is a contradiction, so our supposition is false, and there are infinitely many prime numbers.
solution.note: Notice that this proof does not prove that N = p_1 * p_2 * .... * p_n + 1 is actually a prime number. It only proves that N is not in the list, and not divisible by members of the list. In fact, N is not always prime. For example, consider N = 2 * 3 * 5 * 7 * 11 * 13 + 1 = 30031 = 59 * 509.

subsections.title: B - The Principle of Mathematical Induction

content.text: We use P_n to represent a proposition which is defined for every integer n where n >= a, a in Z. For example, in the case of Example 1, our proposition P_n is: 1/(1*2) + 1/(2*3) + 1/(3*4) + .... + 1/(n(n+1)) = n/(n+1) for all n in Z^+.

content.title: The Principle of Mathematical Induction
content.text: The principle of mathematical induction constitutes a formal proof that a particular proposition is true.
content.statement: Suppose P_n is a proposition which is defined for every integer n >= a, a in Z. If P_a is true, and if P_(k+1) is true whenever P_k is true, then P_n is true for all n >= a.

content.problem: Prove that 4^n + 2 is divisible by 3 for n in Z, n >= 0, by using: (a) the binomial expansion of (1 + 3)^n, (b) the principle of mathematical induction.

steps: If n = 0, 4^0 + 2 = 1 + 2 = 3 which is divisible by 3.
where the contents of the brackets is an integer.
Therefore 4^n + 2 is divisible by 3.

part_b.method: Proof by the principle of mathematical induction
steps: P_n is: 4^n + 2 is divisible by 3 for n in Z, n >= 0.
(1) If n = 0, 4^0 + 2 = 1 + 2 = 3 which is divisible by 3. Therefore P_0 is true.
(2) If P_k is true, then 4^k + 2 = 3A where A is an integer, and so 4^k = 3A - 2.
Now 4^(k+1) + 2 = 4 * 4^k + 2 {using P_k}
= 6(2A - 1) where 6A - 2 is an integer as A in Z.
Thus P_(k+1) is true whenever P_k is true.
Since P_0 is true, and P_(k+1) is true whenever P_k is true, P_n is true for all n in Z, n >= 0. {principle of mathematical induction}
